title: The boy emperor, Ping Di dies of unexpected causes at age 14 Wang Mang alone selects the new emperor, the Ruzi Ying, age 2,ref name=wak1/ starting the ''Jushe'' era of the Han Dynasty.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Candidates for government office must take civil-service examinations.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The imperial Liu clan suspect the intentions of Wang Mang and foment agrarian rebellions during the course of Ruzi Ying's reign. The first of these is led by Liu Chong, Marquess of Ang-Zong (a/k/a Marquis of An-chung), with a small force starting inampref name=wak1/amp May or June.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Roman general Tiberius defeats the Illyrians in Dalmatia on the River Bathinus, but the Great Illyrian Revolt continues.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Vipsania Julia is exiled. Lucius Aemilius Paullus and his family are disgraced.  Augustus breaks off the engagement of Claudius to Paullus' daughter Aemilia Lepida. An effort is made to betrothe Claudius to Livia Medullina.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Marcus Furius Camillus, Sextus Nonius Quinctilianus, and Lucius Apronius become Roman Consuls.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Roman poet Ovid is banished from Rome and exiled to the Black Sea near Tomis (present-day Constan≈£a).
subtitle: Today in history

title: Tincomarus, deposed king of the Atrebates, flees Britain for Rome Eppillus becomes king.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Vonones I becomes king of Parthia.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Start of Chushi era of the Chinese Han Dynasty.
subtitle: Today in history

title: In China, Wang Mang crushes a rebellion by Chai I, and on the winter solstice (which has been dated January 10 of the following year) officially assumes the title emperor, establishing the short-lived Xin Dynasty.ampampKlingaman, William K., ''The First Century: Emperors, Gods and Everyman'', 1990, p 67ampamp
subtitle: Today in history

title: After completing ''Metamorphoses'', Ovid begins the ''Fasti'' (Festivals), 6 books that detail the first 6 months of the year and provide valuable insights into the Roman Calendar.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Germanicus returns to Rome as conquering hero, he celebrates a triumph for his victories over the Cherusci, Chatti and other German tribes west of the Elbe.Tacitus, The Annals 2.41
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Tiberius sends Germanicus to the east in order to lead a military campaign against Parthia.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Cappadocia (Asia Minor) becomes a Roman province.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Lucius Aelius Sejanus becomes Praetorian prefect.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Beginning of a civil war in Germania.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Maroboduus, king of the Marcomanni, is defeated by Arminius and his Germanic tribes.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Tacfarinas, Numidian deserter from the Roman army,ampref name=ampquotref1ampquotampTacitus, The Annals 2.52ampamp begins a guerrilla war against the Romans. He leads his own Musulamii tribe and a coalition of Berbers, attacking the ''Limes Tripolitanus'' a fortified zone (Limes) of the Roman Empire in Africa.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Herod Antipas, son of Herod the Great, builds on the western shore of the Sea of Galilee, the city Tiberias in honor of Tiberius.
subtitle: Today in history

title: An earthquake in Anatolia destroys the city of Sardis and damages several other cities.ampampTacitus, The Annals 2.47ampamp
subtitle: Today in history

title: Publication of the Ab Urbe condita (ampquotHistory of Rome Since its Foundationampquot) in 142 volumes by Livy.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Good Friday) ampndash Crucifixion of Jesus (suggested date, but it is also suggested that he died on April 3, 33).<a href=
>http://www.johnpratt.com/items/docs/newton.html johnpratt.com
subtitle: Today in history

title: Probable beginning of pontificate of Saint Peter (in Catholic reckoning, until 64).
subtitle: Today in history

title: Phaedrus translates Aesop's fables, and composes some of his own.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Velleius Paterculus writes the general history of the countries known in Antiquity.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Good Friday) ampndash Crucifixion of Jesus (according to one dating scheme).
subtitle: Today in history

title: Naevius Sutorius Macro becomes the leader of the Praetorian Guard after Sejanus is executed.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Tiberius returns to Rome from Capri.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Jared conquers the Babylonians according to the Dead Sea Scrolls.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Roman Senate annuls Tiberius's will and proclaims Caligula Roman Emperor.ref name=cambridge
subtitle: Today in history

title: Caligula's attempt to have himself deified creates friction between himself and the Senate.
subtitle: Today in history

title: An earthquake destroys Antioch.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Abilene is granted to Agrippa I.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Saint Peter founds the Syrian Orthodox Church (traditional date).
subtitle: Today in history

title: Probable year of the conversion of the Pharisee Saul of Tarsus to Christianity after a vision.  After 39 he is recognised as Saint Paul.
subtitle: Today in history

title: After a night of negotiation, Claudius is accepted as Emperor by the Senate.ref name=quotClaudiusquot /
subtitle: Today in history

title: Claudius makes Agrippa king of Judea.ampamp
subtitle: Today in history

title: Messalina, wife of Claudius, persuades Claudius to have Seneca the Younger banished to Corsica on a charge of adultery with Julia Livilla.ampamp
subtitle: Today in history

title: Claudius restores religious freedom to Jews throughout the empire,ampamp
subtitle: Today in history

title: An attack across the Rhine by the Germans is stopped by the Romans.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Guangwu of the Han Dynasty deposes his wife, Guo Shentong, as empress, and creates his consort Yin Lihua empress in her place.ampamp
subtitle: Today in history

title: The disciples of Jesus form communities after the Diaspora, especially in Damascus and Antioch.  For the first time they are called Christians.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The death of Caligula saves the Jewish people from being punished for resisting orders to worship his statue in the Temple of Jerusalem.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Roman emperor Claudius dies, possibly after being poisoned by Agrippina, his wife and niece, and is succeeded by Nero.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Nero attempts to prohibit the gladiatorial games.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Under Nero, Rome annexes Aden to protect the maritime route between Alexandria and Asia.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Two centurions are sent to the south of Egypt to find the sources of the Nile, and possible new provinces. They report that while there are many cities in the desert, the area seems too poor to be worthy of conquest.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Gnaeus Domitius Corbulo arrives in the East and take up an assignment as governor of Asia, with a secret brief from Nero and his chief ministers Seneca and Burrus to return Armenia to the Roman Empire.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Corbulo inspects in Syria a base of Legio X Fretensis at Cyrrhus, the Roman legionnaires are demoralized by a ampquotlong peaceampquot. Many soldiers have sold their helmets and shields.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Corbulo recruits Syrian auxiliary units in the region and stationed them in border forts, with orders from Nero not to provoke the Parthians.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Violence erupts in Caesarea regarding the a local ordinance restricting the civil rights of Jews, creating clashes between Jews and pagans. The Roman garrison, made up of Syrians, takes the side of the pagans. The Jews, armed with clubs and swords, meet in the marketplace. The governor of Judea, Antonius Felix, orders his troops to charge. The violence continues and Felix asks Nero to arbitrate.  Nero, sides with the pagans and relegates the Jews to second-class citizens. This decision does nothing but increase the Jews' anger.
subtitle: Today in history

title: In Britain, Venutius leads a revolt against his ex-wife Cartimandua, queen of the Brigantes and a Roman ally. Governor Aulus Didius Gallus sends her military aid, and after some indecisive fighting a legion commanded by Caesius Nasica defeats the rebels (approximate date ‚Äì some time between 52 and 57).
subtitle: Today in history

title: Winter ampampndash Domitius Corbulo marched his legions (Legio VI Ferrata and Legio X) into the mountains of Cappadocia and made camp. He gives the men a harsh training, twenty-five-mile marches and weapons drills.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Judea is returned piecemeal to Agrippa I's son Marcus Julius Agrippa between 48 and 54.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Patriarch Onesimus succeeds Stachys the Apostle as Patriarch of Constantinople.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Paul of Tarsus begins his third mission.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Apollos, a later assistant of Paul, is converted to Christianity in  Ephesus.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Great fire of Rome: A fire begins in the merchant area of Rome and soon burns completely out of control, while emperor Nero allegedly plays his lyre and sings as he watches the blaze from a safe distance. There is no hard evidence to support this claim: fires were very common in Rome at the time. The fire destroys close to one-half of the city and it is officially blamed on the Christians, a small but growing religious movement. Nero is accused of being the arsonist by popular rumour.
subtitle: Today in history

title: In Rome, persecution of early Christians begins under Roman Emperor Nero. Saint Peter is among those executed.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Nero proposes a new urban planning program based the creation of buildings decorated with ornate porticos, the widening of the streets and the use of open spaces. This plan will not be applied until after his death in 68.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Lyon sends a large sum of money to Rome to aid in the reconstruction. However, during the winter of 64‚Äì65, Lyon suffers a catastrophic fire itself, and Nero reciprocates by sending money to Lyon.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Phoenicia becomes part of Syria.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Kushan sack the town of Taxila (in present-day Pakistan).
subtitle: Today in history

title: The year the First Epistle of Peter is traditionally believed to be written.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Seneca proclaims the equality of all men, including slaves.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Nero creates the legion I ''Italica''.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Jewish Revolt (66‚Äì70 AD) commences against the Roman Empire.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Zealots lay siege on Jerusalem and annihilate the Roman garrison (a cohort of Legio III).
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Sicarii capture the fortress of Masada overlooking the Dead Sea.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Cestius Gallus, legate of Syria, marches into Judea and leads a Roman army of 28,000 soldiers to put down the Jewish rebellion. Among the units are Legio III Gallica, Legio XII Fulminata and Legio XXII Primigenia.
subtitle: Today in history

title: November ampampndash Gallus succeeds in conquering Beit She'arim ampquotthe new cityampquot, but is unable to take the Temple in Jerusalem. He retreats to the coast, but is surrounded at Beth-Horon and nearly wiped out by the Zealots.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Gallus arrives in Caesarea, with six thousand men and numerous standards, including the eagle of Legio XII.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Roman Legion II ''Augusta'' is stationed at Gloucester.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Suetonius Paullinus becomes a Roman Consul.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Baekje invades Silla in the Korean peninsula, and captures Castle Ugok.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The First Epistle to Timothy is written (approximate date).
subtitle: Today in history

title: Dioscorides writes his ''De Materia Medica'', a treatise on the methodical treatment of disease by use of medicine.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Halley's Comet is visible.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Roman Senate accepts emperor Galba.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Roman Emperor Nero commits suicide four miles outside Rome. He is deserted by the Praetorian Guard and then stabs himself in the throat.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Legio I ''Macriana liberatrix'' and Legio I ''Adiutrix'' are created.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Lucius Clodius Macer revolts against emperor Nero.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Marcus Ulpius Trajanus, father of Trajan, becomes consul.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Trajan moves to Scythopolis and crosses the Jordan River with Legio X Fretensis. He lays siege to Jericho and destroys the monastery of Qumran, where the Dead Sea Scrolls are originated.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Roman Senate declares Nero as a ''persona non grata''.  In the line of succession, Galba follows Nero.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Winter ampampndash Titus sets up camp at Jericho and the Romans cut off escape routes toward Jerusalem.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Venutius successfully deposes his wife Cartimandua and becomes the ruler of the Brigantes.
subtitle: Today in history

title: An iron chain suspension bridge is constructed in China.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Buddhism officially arrives in China with the building of the White Horse Temple.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Ignatius of Antioch becomes the third bishop of Antioch.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Gospel of Mark is written (approximate date).
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Essenes place the Dead Sea Scrolls in the caves at Qumran.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Roman legions in Germania Superior refuses to swear loyalty to Galba. They rebelled and proclaims Vitellius as emperor.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Lucius Calpurnius Piso Licinianus is adopted by Galba and appointed to deputy Roman Emperor.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Galba and his adopted son Piso are murdered by the Praetorian Guard on the Roman Forum.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Otho seizes power in Rome, proclaims himself emperor, and reigns for three months before committing suicide.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Marcus Trebellius Maximus, governor of Britannia, is forced the flee to Gaul after a mutiny of Legio XX ''Valeria Victrix'' at Deva Victrix (Chester).
subtitle: Today in history

title: First Battle of Bedriacum: Vitellius defeats Otho's legions Otho commits suicide.
subtitle: Today in history

title: After the Battle of Bedriacum, Vitellius becomes emperor.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Marcus Vettius Bolanus becomes the new governor of Britain and faced a second insurrection of Venutius, king of the Brigantes.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Tiberius Julius Alexander orders his legions in Alexandria to swear allegiance to Vespasian as emperor.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Batavian rebellion: The Batavians in Germania Inferior (Netherlands) revolt under the leadership of Gaius Julius Civilis.
subtitle: Today in history

title: German warbands cross over to join the revolt and attack the fortress at Mainz.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Batavians attack Roman forts on the Rhine frontier Fectio and Traiectum (modern Utrecht) are destroyed.
subtitle: Today in history

title: In Gallia Belgica ''cohors II Tungrorum'', raised from the inhabitants of Atuatuca Tungrorum in the north-west of the Ardennes Forest revolt against the Romans.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Danubian legions of Raetia and Moesia proclaims Vespasian as emperor.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Second Battle of Bedriacum: Flavians under Antonius Primus defeat the Vitellians.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Vitellius is captured and murdered by the Gemonian stairs. Vespasian becomes emperor.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Judea: The Jewish Revoltampampnbsp‚Äì Vespasian lays siege to Jerusalem, the city is captured the following year by his son Titus.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Josephus, Jewish rebel leader, is dragged before Vespasian and becomes his historian. He ampquotprophesiedampquot him his elevation to the purple.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Legio I ''Macriana liberatrix'' is disbanded.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Flavian dynasty starts.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Siege of Jerusalem: Titus surrounds the Jewish capital, with three legions (V ''Macedonica'', XII ''Fulminata'' and XV ''Apollinaris'') on the western side and a fourth (X ''Fretensis'') on the Mount of Olives to the east. He puts pressure on the food and water supplies of the inhabitants by allowing pilgrims to enter the city to celebrate Passover and then refusing them egress.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Titus opens a full-scale assault on Jerusalem, he concentrates his attack on the city's Third Wall (HaHoma HaShlishit) to the northwest. The Roman army tries to breach the wall using ''testudos'', mantlets, siege towers, and battering rams.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Third Wall of Jerusalem collapses and the Jews withdraw from Bezetha to the Second Wall, where the defences are unorganized.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Titus and his Roman legions breach the Second Wall of Jerusalem. The Jewish defenders retreats to the First Wall. The Romans built a circumvallation, all trees within fifteen kilometres of the city are cut down.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Titus storms the Fortress of Antonia north of the Temple Mount. The Romans are drawn into street fighting with the Zealots.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Titus destroys the Jewish Temple in Jerusalem. Roman troops are stationed in Jerusalem and abolish the Jewish high priesthood and Sanhedrin. This becomes known as the Fall of Jerusalem, a conclusive event in the First Jewish-Roman War (the Jewish Revolt), which began in 66 AD. Following this event, the Jewish religious leadership moves from Jerusalem to Jamnia (present day Yavne), and this date is mourned annually as the Jewish fast of Tisha B'Av.
subtitle: Today in history

title: AugustampampndashSeptember ampampndash Titus assaults the Temple Mount and detroys Herod's Palace in the Upper City of Jerusalem. Jewish resistance ends on September 26.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Neapolis (present day Nablus) is founded in Iudaea Province.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Naval clashes on the Rhine during the Batavian Revo crew of a captured Roman flagship is imprisoned at Augusta Treverorum (modern Trier).
subtitle: Today in history

title: Roman legions V ''Alaudae'' and XV ''Primigenia'' are destroyed by the Batavi. Later, Quintus Petillius Cerialis puts down the Batavian rebellion of Gaius Julius Civilis.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Vespasian disbanded four Rhine legions (I ''Germanica'', IIII ''Macedonica'', XV ''Primigenia'' and XVI ''Gallica''), disgraced for having surrendered or lost their eagles during the revolt of Julius Civilis.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Later Roman Emperor Domitian marries Domitia Longina.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Romans make a punitive expedition against the Garamantes ‚Äì they are forced to have an official relationship with the Roman Empire.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Annexation of the island of Samothrace by the Empire under Vespasian.
subtitle: Today in history

title: India sees the end of the Hellenistic dynasties.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Expedition by the Roman Septimius Flaccus to southern Egypt. He probably reaches Sudan.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Ze-Hak√®l√© (Zoscales in Greek) becomes king of Aksum.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Avignon becomes the seat of a bishopric.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Members of The Oneida Community, a now non-existent religious group formed in the Nineteenth Century, believed this was the year Jesus Christ returned.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Vespasian dies of fever from diarrhea, his last words on his deathbed are: ''quotI think I'm turning into a god.quot'' Titus succeeds his father as Roman emperor.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Mount Vesuvius erupts, destroying Pompeii, Herculaneum, Stabiae and Oplontis. The Roman fleet based at Misenum, commanded by Pliny the Elder, evacuates refugees but he dies after inhaling volcanic fumes.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Titus dedicates the famous Roman Colosseum.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Chester is founded as a ''castrum'' or Roman fort with the name Deva Victrix. The fortress is built by Legio II Adiutrix and contains barracks, granaries, military baths and headquarters.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Gnaeus Julius Agricola enters Caledonia (modern Scotland) but is resisted by the Caledonians.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Agricola founds Mamucium, a frontier fort and settlement in the North West of England.  This was the first Manchester, a distance to the east of Chester.
subtitle: Today in history

title: To please the Senate, Titus exiles his Jewish mistress, Berenice of Cilicia.
subtitle: Today in history

title: A commission of scholars canonizes the text of works of Confucius and his school.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Domitian is stabbed to death by a freedman at age 44 after a 15-year reign in a palace conspiracy involving officers of the Praetorian Guard. The Flavian dynasty ends.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Nerva is declared emperor by the Senate as the new ruler of the Roman Empire. He recalls citizens exiled by Domitian, this is the beginning of the Era of the Five Good Emperors. The Antonines dynasty starts.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Under Nerva, the Roman Senate regains much of the power usurped by Domitian.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Marcus Ulpius Traianus becomes governor of Upper Germany.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Construction begins on the Forum of Nerva in Rome.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Arch of Titus is completed in Rome.
subtitle: Today in history

title: End of the period covered by Tacitus in his ''Histories''.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Book of Revelation is written (traditional date).
subtitle: Today in history

title: A schism in Buddhism creates a new, popular religion in India, mah√¢y√¢na (Grand Vehicle).
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Nerva recalls his general Marcus Ulpius Trajanus, age 44, from the German frontier and is forced by the Praetorian Guard to adopt him as his successor.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Tacitus advances to consulship.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Roman colony of Cuicul is started in Numidia.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Nerva recognizes the Sanhedrin of Jamnia as an official governmental body of the Jews, and the patriarch or ''nasi'' is designated as the representative of the Jewish people in Rome.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Chinese general Ban Chao orders his lieutenant, Gan Ying, to establish regular relations with the Parthians.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Pope Evaristus succeeds Pope Clement I as the fifth pope (according to Catholic tradition none of the Popes until the mid second century is certain).
subtitle: Today in history

title: Nerva is succeeded by his adopted son Trajan.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Trajan is the first Roman Emperor born in Italica, near Seville. A brilliant soldier and administrator, he enters Rome without ceremony and wins over the public.  Continuing the policies of Augustus, Vespasian and Nerva, he restores the Senate to its full status in the government.  He has a specific vision of the Empire, and keeps a close watch on finances. Taxes, without any increase, are sufficient during his reign to pay the considerable costs of the budget.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The informers used by Domitian to support his tyranny are expelled from Rome.
subtitle: Today in history

title: In order to maintain the Port of Alexandria, Trajan reopens the canal between the Nile and the Red Sea.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Carrying out an idea of Nerva's, Trajan begins a form of state welfare aimed at assuring that poor children are fed and taken care of.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Tacitus finishes his ''Germania'' (approximate date).
subtitle: Today in history

title: The silver content of the Roman denarius rises to 93 percent under emperor Trajan, up from 92 percent under Domitian.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Aqua Traiana is inaugurated by emperor Trajan, the aqueduct channels water from Lake Bracciano,
subtitle: Today in history

title: Osroes I of Parthia succeeds his brother Pacorus II and rules over the western Parthian Empire.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Pliny the Younger is legate to Bithynia.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Christian Church proclaims itself to be universal (catholic).
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Trajan dies of a stroke at Selinus in Cilicia, age 63, while en route from Mesopotamia to Italy. Leaving the Roman Empire at its maximal territorial extent.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Hadrian, who will reign until 138, succeeds him.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Hadrian, a Spaniard like Trajan, is an excellent officer who has had a brilliant career.  He is well-cultured man, who as Emperor inaugurates a civil government,
subtitle: Today in history

title: Hadrian returns large parts of Mesopotamia to the Parthians as part of a peace settlement.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Construction begins on the Pantheon in Rome.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The silver content of the Roman denarius falls to 87 percent under emperor Hadrian, down from 93 percent in the reign of Trajan.
subtitle: Today in history

title: John I becomes the 7th Bishop of Jerusalem.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The building of Hadrian's Wall begins.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Hadrian gives up the territories conquered in Scotland.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Change of era name from ''Jianguang'' (2nd year) to ''Yanguang'' of the Chinese Eastern Han Dynasty.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Hadrian makes Antoninus Pius his successor, on condition that he adopts Marcus Aurelius and Lucius Verus.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Hadrian dies after a heart failure at Baiae, he is buried at Rome in the Gardens of Domitia beside his wife, Vibia Sabina.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Antoninus Pius succeeds Hadrian as Roman Emperor and asks the Senate to confer divine honors for Hadrian.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Construction begins on the Theater of Philadelphia (Amman).
subtitle: Today in history

title: Hadrian's Villa, Tivoli, Italy, is finished.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The silver content of the Roman denarius falls to 75 percent under emperor Antoninus Pius, down from 87 percent under the reign of Hadrian.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Antoninus Pius dies and is succeeded by Marcus Aurelius who shares imperial power with Lucius Verus, although Marcus retains the title Pontifex Maximus.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Marcus Aurelius, a Spaniard like Trajan and Hadrian, is a stoical, disciple of Epictetus, and an energetic man of action.  He pursues the policy of his predecessor and maintains good relations with the Senate. As a legislator, he endeavours to create new principles of morality and humanity, particularly favouring women and slaves.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The weight of a goldpiece, the aureus, is reduced from 7.81 grams under Aurelius to 7.12 grams.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Gaius' ''Institutiones'' are published.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The silver content of the Roman denarius falls to 68 percent under emperor Marcus Aurelius, down from 75 percent under Antoninus Pius.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Marcus Aurelius begins a campaign against the Quadi, who had broken the peace treaty (171). In a violent thunderstorm he defeats and subdues them in the so-called quotmiracle of the rainquot.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Given control of the Eastern Empire, Avidius Cassius, the governor of Syria, crushes an insurrection of shepherds known as the boukoloi.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Marcus Aurelius grants Commodus the rank of ''Imperator'' and makes him Supreme Commander of the Roman legions.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Marcus Aurelius and his son Commodus enter Rome after a campaign north of the Alps and receive a triumph for their victories over the Germanic tribes.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Equestrian Statue of Marcus Aurelius is made. It is now kept at Museo Capitolini in Rome (approximate date).ampamp
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Marcus Aurelius dies after a week's illness at his camp in Vindobona (modern Vienna). He is succeeded by his son Commodus (age 18).
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Era of the Five Good Emperors ends.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Rome creates a 4-mile wide buffer zone by the Danube.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Work begins in Rome on the building of the Column of Marcus Aurelius.
subtitle: Today in history

title: 180ampampndash395 ampampndash Late Empire in Rome.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Porta Nigra is built in Germanian Trier.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Northern Brits from beyond Hadrian's Wall invade the North of modern day England causing Emperor Commodus to allow swathes of Northern cities to establish city walls.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Goths reach the banks of the Black Sea.
subtitle: Today in history

title: This year is often suggested as the first year of the Three Kingdoms period of China.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Lake Taupo erupts, forming ash clouds as far as China and Europe.
subtitle: Today in history

title: In his ''Methodus Medendo'', Greek physician Galen describes the connection between paralysis and the severing of the spinal cord.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Galen's popular work on hygiene is published.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Twelve Christian inhabitants of Scillium in Numidia are executed in Carthage (also in North Africa) (known as the Scillitan Martyrs) ampndash they had refused to swear an oath to the Emperor.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Commodus creates an official cult of the Zoroastrian god Mithra.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Commodus alarms the Senate by appearing dressed as a gladiator for his new consulship (January 1). His mistress, Marcia, finds her name on the imperial execution list and hires the champion wrestler named Narcissus to assassinate Commodus. The Antonines dynasty ends.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Civil war again strikes Rome (192‚Äì193).
subtitle: Today in history

title: The kingdom of Champa begins to control south and central Vietnam (approximate date).
subtitle: Today in history

title: L√º Bu murders his stepfather Dong Zhuo, Chancellor of the Han Dynasty.
subtitle: Today in history

title: A fire destroys Galen's library.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Syrian Christians establish a Christian community in Kerala, India.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Year of the Five Emperors: The Senate chooses Publius  Helvius Pertinax, against his will to succeed the late Commodus as Emperor.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Pertinax is forced to reorganize the handling of finances, which was wrecked under Commodus, and to reestablish discipline in the Roman army.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Pertinax suspend the food programs established by Trajan, this provokes the ire of the Praetorians.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Pertinax is assassinated by members of the Praetorian Guard, who storm the imperial palace. The Empire is  auctioned off, Marcus Didius Julianus the highest bidder, offers 300 million sesterces for the throne.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Lucius Septimius Severus is proclaimed Emperor by his troops in Illyricum (Balkans). He marches with his army (16 legions) to Rome.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Roman governors Clodius Albinus (Britannia) and Pescennius Niger (Syria) claim with support of their troops the imperial throne.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Septimius Severus enters the capital and has Julianus put to death. He replaces the Praetorian Guard with a 15,000 man force from the Danubian legions.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Septimius Severus finally gains control of the Roman Empire, in Britain Clodius Albinus allies with him and accepted the title of Caesar. The Severan dynasty starts.
subtitle: Today in history

title: British tribes take advantage of the disorder by the civil war and damage Hadrian's Wall. Extensive repairs to the defence work is carried out by the legionaries.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Septimius Severus defeats the army under Pescennius at the Battle of Cyzicus and Battle of Nicaea (Asia Minor).
subtitle: Today in history

title: Counterfeiting workshops begin to appear throughout the Roman Empire.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Last (4th) year of ''Chuping'' era of the Chinese Han Dynasty.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The silver content of the Roman denarius falls to 50 percent under emperor Septimius Severus, down from 68 percent under Marcus Aurelius.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Battle of Lugdunum: Emperor Septimius Severus defeats the self-proclaimed emperor Decimus Clodius Albinus at Lugdunum (modern Lyon). Albinus commits suicide, legionaries sack the town.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Septimius Severus returns to Rome and has about 30 of Albinus's supporters in the Senate executed. After his victory he declares himself the adopted son of the late Marcus Aurelius.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Septimius Severus forms new naval units, manning all the triremes in Italy with heavily armed troops for war in the East. Soldiers embarked on an artificial canal between the Tigris and Euphrates.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Legio I, II, and III ''Parthica'' are levied by Septimius Severus for his Parthian campaign.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Roman army marched east to repel a Parthian invasion of Mesopotamia, they loot the royal palace at Ctesiphon and capture an enormous number of its inhabitants as slaves.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Septimius Severus reconstitutes the Province of Mesopotamia under an equestrian governor commanding two legions.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Septimius Severus, who had spared the Senate at the beginning of his reign, now excludes it from controlling the Roman empire by declaring a military dictatorship.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Galen's major work on medicines, ''Pharmacologia'', is published.
subtitle: Today in history

title: A Christian council is held in Edessa.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Cao Cao writes ''Du«én Ge X√≠ng''.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Cao Cao marches south with his army and captures the enemy fleet at Jiangling.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Liu Bei escapes from Cao Cao at the Battle of Changban.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Zhou Yu and Liu Bei defeat Cao Cao at the Battle of Red Cliffs along with the Battle of Yamen and Battle of Lake Poyang, this is one of the largest naval battles in China's history.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Marcus Aurelius Antoninus Augustus and his brother Publius Septimius Geta Caesar become Roman Consuls.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Septimius Severus leads an expedition (20,000 men) in Britannia, crosses Hadrian's Wall and moves through eastern Scotland. The Roman army pushes the Caledonians back to the River Tay and Severus signs a peace treaty. He repairs the Antonine Wall (his repairs are sometimes called the Severan Wall).
subtitle: Today in history

title: Britain is divided in the north, Lower Britain (Britannia Inferior) administered from the fortress at Eburacum (modern York), and in the south, Upper Britain (Britannia Superior) controlled by the legions at Deva Victrix and Isca Augusta, with its capital at Londinium (London).
subtitle: Today in history

title: King Vologases VI succeeds his father Vologases V to the throne. His brother Artabanus IV of Media begins a rebellion against him in the Parthian Empire.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Ardashir I, ruler of Istakhr (Persia), revolts against his brother and founds the Sassanid dynasty.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Caracalla and his brother Geta succeed their father Septimius Severus as joint Roman Emperors.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Geta is lured to come without his bodyguards to meet Caracalla, to discuss a possible reconciliation. When he arrives the Praetorian Guard murders him and he dies in the arms of his mother Julia Domna.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Caracalla persecutes Geta's supporters and sympathizers, soldiers are allowed to wreak havoc in the streets of Rome. The bloodshed lasts for two weeks, and one contemporary source claims 20,000 people are killed.
subtitle: Today in history

title: January ampampndash Cao Cao writes ''R√†ng Xi√†n Z√¨ M√≠ng Bƒõn Zh√¨ L√¨ng'' (ËÆìÁ∏£Ëá™ÊòéÊú¨Âøó‰ª§)
subtitle: Today in history

title: Ardashir I becomes king of part of Persia.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Baths of Caracalla are started to be built (approximate date).
subtitle: Today in history

title: Mark is succeeded by Philadelphus as Patriarch of Constantinople.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Caracalla is assassinated by his legionaries near Edessa. Marcus Opellius Macrinus head of the Praetorian Guard, declares himself Roman emperor.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Summer ampampndash Battle of Nisibis: The Roman army under command of Macrinus, is defeated in a three days battle by the Parthians at Nisibis (southern Turkey).
subtitle: Today in history

title: King Artabanus IV signs a peace treaty with Rome after he received 200 million sesterces, for the rebuilding of towns destroyed during the war in Parthia.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Macrinus, of Mauritania, becomes the first equestrian Roman emperor.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Empress Julia, wife of Septimius Severus and mother of Caracalla and Geta, commits suicide.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Colosseum is badly damaged by fire (lightning) which destroys the wooden upper levels of the amphitheater.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The papacy of Zephyrinus ends. Callixtus I is elected as the  sixteenth pope, but is opposed by the theologian Hippolytus who accuses him of laxity and of being a Modalist, one who denies any distinction between the three persons of the Trinity.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Hippolytus begins his ampquotpontificateampquot as antipope and sets up a breakaway church for Christian fowlers.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Ciriacus succeeds Philadelphus as Patriarch of Constantinople.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Julia Maesa, an aunt of the assassinated Caracalla, is banished to her home in Syria by the self-proclaimed emperor Macrinus and declares her grandson Elagabalus, age 14, emperor of Rome.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Battle of Antioch: Elagabalus defeats with support of the Syrian legions the forces of Macrinus. Macrinus flees, but is captured near Chalcedon and later executed in Cappadocia.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Diadumenianus, son of Macrinus, escapes to the Parthian court, but is captured at Zeugma and also put to death.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The silver content of the Roman denarius falls to 43 percent under emperor Elagabalus, down from 50 percent under Septimius Severus, as he empties the treasury with his excesses while his grandmother, Julia Maesa, rules the Empire.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Elagabalus adopts his cousin Alexander Severus as his heir and  receives the title of Caesar.
subtitle: Today in history

title: July ampampndash Elagabalus is forced to divorce Aquilia Severa and marries his third wife Annia Faustina. After five months he returns to Severa and claims that the original divorce is invalid. The marriage is symbolic, because Elagabalus appears to be homosexual or bisexual. According to the historian Cassius Dio, he has a stable relationship with his chariot driver, the slave Hierocles.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Liu Bei, Chinese warlord and descendant of the royal family of the Han Dynasty, proclaims himself emperor in Sichuan and establish the Kingdom of Shu Han. Three kingdoms arise ampampndash the Wei in the north, the Wu in the south and the Shu Han in the west.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Elagabalus is assassinated, along with his mother, Julia Soaemias, by the Praetorian Guard during a revolt. Their mutilated bodies are dragged through the streets of Rome before being thrown into the Tiber.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Alexander Severus succeeds Elagabalus. He is only 13 years old, his mother, Julia Avita Mamaea, governs the Roman Empire with the help of Domitius Ulpianus and a council composed of 16 senators.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Three Kingdoms: Eastern Wu is established in China. Emperor Liu Bei invades with an army (100,000 men) the border of Eastern Wu in the Battle of Yiling to retake the Jing province. However, because of a tactical mistake, Liu Bei's military camps are destroyed by forces of Sun Quan.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The silver content of the Roman denarius falls to 35 percent under emperor Alexander Severus, down from 43 percent under Elagabalus.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Pope Callixtus I is killed by a mob in Rome's Trastevere after a 5-year reign in which he has stabilized the Saturday fast three times per year, with no food, oil, or wine to be consumed on those days. Callixtus is succeeded by cardinal Urban I.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Cao Pi dies after a illness, his son Cao Rui succeeds him as emperor of the Kingdom of Wei.
subtitle: Today in history

title: King Ardashir I, ruler of the Sassanid dynasty, defeats Artabanus IV and is crowned ampquotKing of Kingsampquot of the Persian Empire. Beginning of the 400 year-reign of the Sassanid Empire.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Empire of Parthia falls.
subtitle: Today in history

title: A merchant from the Roman Empire called ampquotQin Lunampquot by the Chinese, arrives in Jiaozhi (modern Hanoi) and is taken to see Sun Quan, king of Eastern Wu, who requests him to make a report on his native country and people. He is given an escort for the return trip including a present of ten male and ten female ampquotblackish-coloured dwarfs.ampquot However, the officer in charge of the Chinese escort dies and Qin Lun has to continue his journey home alone.ampamp<a href=
>http://depts.washington.edu/uwch/silkroad/texts/weilue/weilue.html An annotated translation of the ''Weilue''ampamp
subtitle: Today in history

title: Pope Pontian succeeds Pope Urban I as the eighteenth pope.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Patriarch Castinus succeeds Patriarch Ciriacus I as Patriarch of Constantinople.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Seventy Bishops hold the Council of the Christian Church of Africa.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Alexander Severus and his mother Julia Mamaea are murdered by legionaries near Moguntiacum (modern Mainz), Legio XXII ''Primigenia'' mutinied. The Severan dynasty ends.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Maximinus Thrax, age 62, is proclaimed emperor. He has a Gothic father and an Alan mother. Maximinus a Thracian, is the first foreigner to hold the Roman throne.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Crisis of the Third Century: The Roman Empire is under pressure by the Alemanni, Franks, Goths, Quadi and Sassanids (Persia).
subtitle: Today in history

title: Future Emperor of Cao Wei, Cao Fang, is instated as the Prince of Qi.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Pope Pontian resigns. He and Hippolytus, church leader of Rome, are exiled to the mines of Sardinia. Emperor Maximinus persecutes the Christians.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Pope Anterus succeeds Pontian as the nineteenth pope.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Origen makes revisions to the Septuagint.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Pope Fabian succeeds Pope Anterus as the twentieth pope.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Fabian separates Rome into seven deaconships.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Fabian sends seven missionaries to Gaul to evangelize in the large cities.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Roman subjects in Africa revolt against Maximinus and elect Marcus Antonius Gordianus (Africanus) as emperor. He is a rich descendant of the Gracchi and the late emperor Trajan. Gordianus yields to public demand that he succeed Maximinus and rules jointly with his 46-year old son Gordian II.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Battle of Carthage: Numidian forces loyal to Maximinus invade Africa with support of Legio III ''Augusta''. Gordian II is killed and after a siege of 36 days, Gordian I commits suicide by hanging himself with his belt.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Year of the Six Emperors: The Senate outlaws Maximinus for his bloodthirsty proscriptions in Rome and nominates two of its members, Pupienus and Balbinus, to the throne.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Maximinus advances to the town Aquileia in northern Italy, his army suffers from famine and disease, while the city is besieged. Soldiers of Legio II ''Parthica'' killed him in his tent, along with his son Maximinus (who is appointed co-emperor). Their corpses are decapitated and their heads carried to Rome.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Praetorian Guard stormed the palace and capture Pupienus and Balbinus. They are dragged naked through the streets of Rome and executed. On the same day Gordian III, age 13, is proclaimed new emperor. Timesitheus becomes his tutor and advisor.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Future Roman Emperor Valerian becomes ''princeps senatus''.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Colosseum is restored after being damaged.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Goths, coming from Ukraine, cross the Danube and devastate the Roman Empire up to the border with Anatolia.
subtitle: Today in history

title: In North Africa, Legio III ''Augusta'', is dissolved.  Until its reconstitution in 253, Africa is defended by auxiliary forces only.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Cao Wei general Sima Yi destroys the outlying northeastern Chinese warlord Gongsun Yuan in his Liaodong campaign.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The silver content of the Roman denarius falls to 28 percent under emperor Gordianus III, down from 35 percent under Alexander Severus.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Battle of Samhain is fought in Ireland.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Gordian III is murdered by mutinous soldiers in Zaitha (Mesopotamia). A mound is raised at Carchemish in his memory.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Philip the Arab declares himself co-emperor and makes a disgraceful peace with the Persians. He evacuates Syria and gives Shapur I 500,000 gold pieces.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Philip the Arab constructs the city of Shahba (Syria), the province of his birth. The Persians occupied Armenia.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Philip the Arab is recognized by the Roman Senate as new Roman Emperor and gives his brother Priscus supreme power (''rector Orientis'') in the Eastern provinces.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Philippus I is proclaimed ''Augustus'', he nominates his son Philippus, age 6, with the title of ''Caesar'' and heir to the throne.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Guanqiu Jian of Cao Wei invades Goguryeo, devastating their capital.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Plotinus, Greek philosopher, escapes the bloodshed that accompanies the murder of Gordianus III and makes his way to Antioch. Back to Rome he founds his Neoplatonist school and attracts students like Porphyry, Castricius Firmus and Eustochius of Alexandria.
subtitle: Today in history

title: 244ampampndash249 ampampndash Philip the Arab, is made. It is now kept at Musei Vaticani, Braccio Nuovo, Rome.
subtitle: Today in history

title: 244ampampndash245 ampampndash House-synagogue, Dura-Europos, Syria, is built. It is reconstructed in the National Museum of Damascus (Syria).
subtitle: Today in history

title: The silver content of the Roman denarius falls to 0.5 percent under emperor Philippus I, down from 28 percent under Gordian III.
subtitle: Today in history

title: In the Battle of Abrittus, the Goths defeat emperor Decius and his son Herennius Etruscus on swampy ground in the Dobrudja (Moesia).
subtitle: Today in history

title: In Rome, Hostilian, son of Decius, succeeds his father, while Trebonianus Gallus is proclaimed Emperor by the troops. Gallus accepts him as co-emperor, but an outbreak of plague strikes the city and kills the young Hostilian.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The prosperity of Roman Britain declines during this period as the Germanic tribes of the Franks and Saxons, whose homelands are in Friesland and the Low Countries, make raids around the southeast coast.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Gallus makes peace with the Goths, he permits them to keep their plunder, and offers them a bribe not to return.
subtitle: Today in history

title: A fifteen-year plague begins in the Roman Empire.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Sassanid king, Shapur I, orders an invasion of the Roman East with the intent of finally capturing the jewel of Syria, Antioch (251‚Äì254).
subtitle: Today in history

title: March ampampndash Pope Cornelius succeeds Pope Fabian as the 21st pope.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Pope Lucius I succeeds Pope Cornelius as the 22nd pope.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Lucius is arrested almost immediately following his election and also exiled.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Pope Stephen I succeeds Pope Lucius I as the 23rd pope.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Pope Sixtus II succeeds Pope Stephen I as the 24th pope.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Valerian's persecution of Christians begins: his edict orders bishops and priests to sacrifice according to the pagan rituals, and prohibits Christians, under penalty of death, from meeting at the tombs of their deceased.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Pope Dionysius dies at Rome after a 9-year reign and is succeeded by Pope Felix I.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Pope Felix I succeeds Pope Dionysius as the 26th pope.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Paul of Samosata is deposed as Patriarch of Antioch (though he is not removed until 272).
subtitle: Today in history

title: Aurelian has a temple dedicated to Sol Invictus on the third day after the solstice and day of rebirth of the Sun. This religion, which is in essence monotheistic, becomes the state religion of Rome.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Britain rebels over the value of coinage.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Kingdom of Aksum attains great prosperity thanks to its control of Red Sea trade.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Pope Felix I dies in Rome after a 5-year reign.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Japanese shipwrights build a 100-foot oar-powered vessel for Emperor ≈åjin. The Japanese will not use sails for another 7 centuries.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Pope Eutychian
subtitle: Today in history

title: Marcus Claudius Tacitus is proclaimed Emperor by the Senate, his half brother Marcus Annius Florianus becomes Praetorian Prefect.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Gaul is pillaged by the Franks and the Alemanni.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Pallava dynasty begins in Southern India.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Pope Caius succeeds Pope Eutychian as the 28th pope.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Gaius Aurelius Valerius Diocletianus, age 39, is proclaimed new emperor. He establish himself at Nicomedia (modern ƒ∞zmit, Turkey) and accepts the purple imperial vestments.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Diocletianus carries out reforms the Roman army returns to conscription,  and admits large numbers of barbarian volunteers. The old organisation of Roman legions and auxilia is abandoned.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Sabinus Julianus, Roman usurper against Emperor Carinus, revolts in Pannonia. He invades northern Italy and declares himself emperor.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Winter ampampndash Diocletianus advanced with his army across the Balkans.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Patriarch Rufinus I succeeds Patriarch Dometius as Patriarch of Constantinople.
subtitle: Today in history

title: r July 25 ampndash Diocletian appoints his fellow-officer Maximian to the office of Caesar, or junior co-emperor.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Carausius, naval commander at Bononia (modern Boulogne), is given the task to clear the English Channel of Frankish and Saxon pirates.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Maximian is sent to pacify Gaul. Here the Bagaudae, a band of peasants, revolt against the Roman Empire.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Late summer ampampndash Diocletian defends the Danube against Sarmatian raids. He transfers his capital to Nicomedia (Turkey).
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Diocletian elevates his friend Maximian to co-emperor, giving him the title Augustus. The Bagaudae are crushed, after their revolt in Gaul.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Carausius, commander of the ''Classis Britannica'', is accused of piracy and sentenced to death. He responds by declaring himself emperor of Britain and Northwestern Gaul. His forces comprise of the newly built Roman fleet and three legions in Britain. The Carausian Revolt is supported by Gaulish merchant ships and barbarian mercenaries.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Diocletian divides the empire in two, after economic and military problems. He gives Maximian control over the Western Roman Empire and appoints himself ruler of the Eastern Roman Empire (later known as the Byzantine Empire).
subtitle: Today in history

title: Tuoba Chuo succeeds his brother Tuoba Xilu as chieftain of the Tuoba clan.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Jin Wudi, founder of the Western Jin Dynasty, dies after a 25-year reign. He reunifies north and south, but gives away  many dukedoms to his kinsmen. Crown Prince Jin Huidi succeeds his father and has to deal with conflicts among the aristocratic families in China.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Diocletian and Maximian appoint Constantius Chlorus and Galerius as Caesars. This is considered the beginning of the Tetrarchy, known as the ''Quattuor Principes Mundi'' (quotFour Rulers of the Worldquot).
subtitle: Today in history

title: The four Tetrarchs establish their capitals close to the Roman frontier:
subtitle: Today in history

title: Nicomedia (northwestern Asia Minor) becomes the capital of Diocletian
subtitle: Today in history

title: Mediolanum (Milan, near the Alps) becomes the capital of Maximian
subtitle: Today in history

title: Augusta Treverorum (Trier, in Germany) becomes the capital of Constantius Chlorus
subtitle: Today in history

title: Sirmium (Serbia, on the Danube border) becomes the capital of Galerius
subtitle: Today in history

title: Diocletian's Palace is built at a small bay on the Dalmatian coast, four miles from Salona, today's Split, Croatia.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Constantius Chlorus retakes some of the Gallic territories and conquers the crucial port of Bononia (modern Boulogne).
subtitle: Today in history

title: Carausius, Roman usurper, is murdered by his finance minister Allectus who proclaims himself ampquotemperorampquot of Britain.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Constantius Chlorus defeats the Franks on the Rhine frontier in Batavia (Netherlands).
subtitle: Today in history

title: King Tiridates III of Armenia, (with Rome as suzerainty) invades Assyria.
subtitle: Today in history

title: King Bahram II of the Persian Empire dies after a 17-year reign, his son Bahram III ascends to the throne. After four months he is murdered by viceroy Narseh with support of the nobility.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Narseh becomes king of Persia and engaged Rome in eight years of constant warfare.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Tuoba Fu succeeds his uncle Tuoba Chuo as chieftain of the Chinese Tuoba clan.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Probus succeeds Rufinus as Patriarch of Constantinople.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Pope Caius dies at Rome after a 13-year reign and is succeeded by Pope Marcellinus as the 29th pope.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Maximian concludes his campaign in North Africa against the Berbers, and makes a triumphal entry into Carthage.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Baths of Diocletian are commissioned by Maximian in honor of Emperor Diocletian. Christians are expelled from the Roman army.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Galerius invades Armenia with an army of 25,000 men. He makes personal reconnaissances, and marched deep in occupied Mesopotamia.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Battle of Satala: Galerius decisively defeats king Narseh. He captures the Persian camp, including Narseh's family, harem and treasure.
subtitle: Today in history

title: King Tridates III is restored as ruler of Armenia.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The manufacture of cultured silk becomes popular from Korea to Japan.
subtitle: Today in history
